newsitem.title: ZAMBIA: Ex-ZCCM workers seek to reopen Kabwe mine.
newsitem.headline: Ex-ZCCM workers seek to reopen Kabwe mine.

text.p: A group of former Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) workers have signed a contract to buy the Kabwe lead and zinc mine which was closed in June 1994.
A ZCCM spokesman said Kabwe Power and Metal Ltd (KPM) would acquire 85 percent of the mine's assets for 1.1 billion kwacha (about $915,000).
The group then plans to pump in more than 60 billion kwacha to resuscitate operations.
KPM chairman Kizito Mumbi said the former mine employees had used their terminal benefits to procure the mine's assets and were now seeking international finance to develop the mine.
"We have approached a number of international financial institutions, and three are very interested in the project. Two of them are European and one is American," he said.
"They have not yet committed themselves to financing the project, but are very keen to conduct their own feasibility studies in the project."
The mines new owners plan to go into the production of lead and zinc, as well as offering engineering products and services.
KPM would process waste dump material at the rate of 240,000 tonnes of slag per year, producing 54,000 tonne of oxide material each year for between 25 and 30 years.
It expected to export 70 percent of its products.
KPM was formed by some 300 miners who were laid off when the loss-making mine was closed.

"Immediately after the closure of the mine was announced, a team of Kabwe Mine employees saw an opportunity staring them in the face. Putting their heads together, they mooted a plan to take advantage of that opportunity," ZCCM director of human resouces, Urban Chishimba said.
"We are confident that the KPM will marshall their individual and collective technical expertise to make this venture a success story," he added.
